replies.body:
A bunch of people who didn't like Taliyah were asking to change Taliyah into something they liked.
Meanwhile, a bunch of players were actually playing Taliyah instead of posting on the boards because they liked her.
When Riot changed Taliyah to appeal to people who didn't play her, suddenly her players had a reason to go to the boards.

Yeah, this is usually what happens when people don't like a change. The people who asked for the change were the ones being vocal then, and the people who object to the change are the ones vocal after because they get more attention for voicing thejr disdain once the change goes live.

Some people fail to recognize that it's a DIFFERENT group of people who asked for the change than the ones complaining about it.

That said, there's also the case where the change was popular in concept but after people get a taste of it they change their minds (either because they're just hard to please, or because the change was implemented badly *cough* DQ *cough*)

There's also the case that people generally don't know what they want until they see it. Everyone's most likely seen something on for example a restaurant menu and thought "ooh, that sounds good. I'll take that". Up until that point you had no idea you wanted that meal.
In this case it's the reverse in that they thought "ooh I want that" and then when they get what they thought they wanted they realize they didn't actually want it.

And people say "if someone likes something they downvote who thinks otherwise so posts with lots of upvotes are legit!1!!1"

Boards will never learn.

I'd argue its different people complaining about it though?

Not to mention the boards here tend to hate Reddit anyways.

Yeah, the people who wanted vector cast are the noob Tali players who only played her once or twice & didn't bother trying to ACTUALLY learn her.

The people who want the old W casting back are the players who ACTUALLY took the time to learn how to play around the W.

This is clearly a case of inexperience vs the experienced.

Or it's a bunch of people who learned something (for better or worse) that don't want that something changed.  

The way you put it makes it sound like there's a good reason for the old way over the new.

Especially when her core functionality on her old W could only work with one combo - EW and that was it.

>This is clearly a case of inexperience vs the experienced.

This is somewhat true but not entirely. People that could stomach her W and took it on as a challenge had gotten used to it and people who found the spell to irritating to use stopped playing her because of one ability alone.

Finally someone gets it.

"I have 100~150 games on Taliyah and -I- did it with the old way of casting! now I hate the new way!"

It makes it sound like you're basically faulting these people for not playing a champion that, for whatever reason, didn't appeal to them mechanically.

That said I put a pretty good effort into Taliyah and never found her to be anything special, but I didn't feel that her old W cast particularly strengthened her gameplay. I've mostly been laughing about the people trying to tell me vector casting 1 ability takes longer than casting the same ability twice (lol). If that's true, you need to pick up a slower paced game... Cause my cast time for Taliyah's W went from maybe .5~1 second to like .15~.25 at most, and I've found it to be much more reliable.

I totally understand people being upset that they learned it a certain way, but a lot of people (not you) come at it from this place of "Well I am a Taliyah main (Kappa) and I CLEARLY understand this champion better than the designers or the players". Let's stop calling people who wanted vector cast "noobs", because I was for it as well if nothing else because it's more inline with the rest of the game mechanics (and it really seems faster now, much more reliable, and though the indicator could use some QoL I think it's a superior method of casting, mechanically). Does being unhappy with Taliyah's W and choosing not to play her as a result somehow make me unskilled at the game? I don't see why - I chose to wait until Riot either buffed the character or changed the cast paradigm because I found it lacking. As someone who has been playing since season 1, I don't feel that I couldn't have learned Taliyah's W with the previous cast method, but rather I just didn't think she was that great (and as a support main seeing her with a 30% winrate in support didn't make me very confident in picking her for that role).

tl;dr: taliyah mains need to stop coming into threads and immediately insulting anyone who has an opinion who didn't "main" the champ on release, or nobody will ever take you seriously. if you have a legitimate problem back it up with logic and reasoning not "well I learned it the old way and the old way is better".

One current problem is the fact that the target reticle doesn't match what the skill does. It's clear that this is a result of laziness.

Another problem is the fact that the skill doesn't give the player the option to knock people vertically upwards anymore, which restricts the freedom. If you're wondering why you would want to do that, read what people have to say in the other topic. 

Another problem is that it doesn't mesh with Taliyah's playstyle. She's a roaming movement speed-based mage that has to move all the time. The time it takes you to click and then drag is already too much time wasted when you're trying to hit someone like Hecarim. The old W lets you select an area of the ground and whether or not you wanted to, you can push, pull, or shove to the side. There is a huge difference and I noticed right off the bat. 

Honestly, the change just isn't good because it's so lazily implemented. I'm not saying Vector Casting is bad, but Taliyah's W needs a completely different casting control scheme at this point because it doesn't fit Taliyah at all.

I think "I feel that the new change makes Taliyah's gameplay change" isn't really a valid argument. The post you quote is actually one of my major problems - it definitely does not take me anywhere near .25~.35 seconds to vector cast Taliyah's W. It's instant. With smart cast with indicator on you can literally press W and flick your mouse and release W and you're done - MAYBE, just maybe .1 second longer than normally casting a spell, but it's not challenging at all to cast the spell faster once you're familiar with the paradigm.

Not liking a change because it feels wrong or is different from what you experienced before is fine, but there are people all over the threads claiming she's ruined and dead and she's gonna lose 10% more winrate and..,

To be clear, I don't mind that there are people unhappy about vector cast - lots of changes happen in this game every day that I disagree with. But most of the posts supporting the other side use logic and "math" that is completely made up. And I'm incredibly confused as to how removing spell lockout made her LESS mobile.

A month ago she came out, after playing her for a month people realized that the way W was cast was completely fine, but riot in their infinite wisdom thinks "If they complained about it but stopped that means they still want it", must explain solo q "If they complain about it all the time they don't want it"
I thought the change was going to be good but it feels clumsy it don't respond like it should basically if you move your cursor too fast you miss place the skill

Here's the other side of the coin, I'm ready for the downvotes

I'm a Viktor main. I have plenty of practice with his vector casting and it's one of the quickest and easiest skills to cast to me, specifically beuacse im used to it.
When Taliyah came out and I tested her on PBE, I was shocked and confused that her W didn't already have vector casting, because, at least in my opinion, that would be the simplest way to throw someone. I actually stopped playing her because I couldn't get the W to do what i wanted to, and I repeatedly tried to cast it like Viktor's E.
 
Obviously i had no practice with Taliyah's original W, so i was bad at it. If you really do enjoy playing Taliyah, you'll just have to get more practice with the casting and you'll eventually see its quick and fluid, perfect to be running and jumping around with. No vertical knockup will definitely be missed, but it just may be worth it.

Here's the thing, though: Unlike Viktor and Rumble, Taliyah's W has a delay before actually knocking people away, part of this being visible to the enemy. Vector casting makes sense on an almost instant damaging spell that travels in a line, but not on a time-sensitive, ground-targeted circle with a delay. The fact that the casting doesn't start until you release W as opposed to before where it started on press-down, means that another layer of prediction is involved of the Taliyah player on top of the already existing delay. It makes it worse in clutch situations(by a lot), which also means it's a worse ability now in higher levels of play. Other than that, Viktor or Rumble hardly ever need to cast their spells in max range, while Taliyah needs to more often, especially if you've internalized the range.

Also, the lock-out removal essentially makes her a bad Viktor clone with a burst-mage profile, an unreliable combo and semi-global non-damaging ult. Before, landing her E>W required planning, zoning and outplaying/outsmarting your opponent because it was so telegraphed, so the interaction was very engaging and offered counterplay for the opponent. Now you rely more on dumb luck, because if you land the W you land everything else, and her W is unreliable/easily dodged.

It's not only a question of having to learn a new way of casting(which I think many Taliyah players won't mind) it's that it's now inferior when mastered compared to the old one when mastered. It's also not about which casting is better overall, it's that the old W casting was a better fit for a spell like that, because it's a spell that's different from Viktors and Rumbles spells, even if they can be cast in the same way. If you want to try a simulation of how it feels for a Taliyah main to cast the new W, try playing a champion with skillshots you know very well(except for Viktor and Rumble), and enable quick-cast with indicator on all spells.

I mean, I was very vocal about not changing to vector cast, and I still don't like it, but the reasoning made sense if you actually read Zenon's post. Vector is, strictly speaking, a faster input method, since it requires one button press and a mouse movement, instead of two button presses and a mouse movement. The reason they changed to vector was to complement the fact that Taliyah no longer had a lockout on her other spells, and, while it is not absolutely necessary (you can still hit WEW in the delay time), it's just faster.

Personally vector cast still makes no intuitive sense to me, so I still can't play it. On the plus side, if I ever invest enough time to learn it, I'll be able to play Viktor and Rumble as well, who are two champions I've always wanted to play but never could because of vector casting.

Pretty much this. 

Introducing an entirely new casting paradigm over the already-existing cast-and-release method of vector casting was a mistake. Now Taliyah has a control-scheme consistent with other league champions and will be more accessible for it. Especially at higher levels of play where fluid command inputs are absolutely necessary to perform.
